NODE_TEXT:
In this case, the device independently determines if the signal has a data rate of 10 Mbps, 100 Mbps, or 1,000 Mbps. No explicit setting has to be made.

Autonegotiation enables the devices involved to negotiate the transmission conditions before data packets are transmitted. In so doing both the transmission rate (10/100/1000 Mbps) as well as the transmission mode are negotiated. Half-duplex or full-duplex are the options for the transmission method.

The following applies as of PCS 7 V6.1: Retain the factory settings.

Note

The only time you need to manually set the two components on the patch cable to a uniform transmission setting, for example 100 Mbps full-duplex, is when one of the components on the plant bus or terminal bus does not support the autonegotiation function. Deviating settings may lead to unpredictable error scenarios.

Compendium Part A - Configuration Guidelines (V9.0)

Configuration Manual, 03/2018, A5E43228900-AA

Q: What is the purpose of autonegotiation in network devices as described in the 'Compendium Part A - Configuration Guidelines (V9.0)'?
A1: Autonegotiation allows devices to automatically determine and agree on the transmission rate and mode before data transmission begins.
A2: It enables devices to negotiate both the speed (10/100/1000 Mbps) and the transmission mode (half-duplex or full-duplex) without manual configuration.
A3: The purpose is to facilitate automatic setting of transmission conditions, including data rate and duplex mode, ensuring compatible communication between devices.
A4: Autonegotiation is used to automatically establish the optimal transmission settings between devices, eliminating the need for manual configuration.
A5: To automatically negotiate and set the transmission rate and mode, ensuring efficient and error-free data communication between network devices.

Q: What are the transmission modes that can be negotiated through autonegotiation according to the 'Compendium Part A - Configuration Guidelines (V9.0)'?
A1: Half-duplex and full-duplex are the transmission modes that can be negotiated.
A2: The negotiable transmission modes include half-duplex, where communication is one direction at a time, and full-duplex, allowing simultaneous two-way communication.
A3: Autonegotiation can set the devices to operate in either half-duplex or full-duplex mode based on mutual agreement.
A4: Two modes: half-duplex (sequential communication) and full-duplex (simultaneous two-way communication) are options.
A5: Devices can automatically agree to communicate in half-duplex or full-duplex mode through autonegotiation.

Q: Under what condition must the transmission settings be manually configured as per the 'Compendium Part A - Configuration Guidelines (V9.0)'?
A1: Manual configuration is required when one of the components does not support autonegotiation.
A2: If a device on the plant bus or terminal bus lacks autonegotiation capability, settings like 100 Mbps full-duplex must be manually set.
A3: When autonegotiation is unsupported by any component, uniform transmission settings must be manually established to prevent errors.
A4: Deviating from autonegotiation requires manual setting of transmission parameters to avoid unpredictable errors.
A5: Manual configuration is necessary only in cases where autonegotiation functionality is absent in any connected device.

A2: It eliminates the need for manual intervention, ensuring devices communicate optimally without configuration mistakes.
A3: Preferable because it dynamically adjusts to the highest mutually supported settings, avoiding compatibility issues.
A4: Autonegotiation is favored as it ensures devices automatically configure themselves for the best performance.
A5: It's preferred for its ability to automatically establish the most efficient communication parameters between devices.
